To those who at first sight may think
that the papers written, before the abolition
of the system by the decree of the legislature,
are now out of date & should have been
suppressed, the Compiler ventures to suggest
that even if the appointed apprenticeship of
five or seven years were already expired,
yet the past sorrows of the negro, & our
long-continued apathy in disregarding his
bitter griefs, should not be speedily be for-
gotten, but often remembered with deep
humility before God––"We have been verily
guilty concerning our Brother, in that we
saw the anguish of his soul, when he
besought us & we would not hear."

After the perusal of these pieces, The
Editor is convinced that no one can think
an apology necessary for their publication––
their intrinsic value & beauty must com
_mend them to every one.

Besides though Slavery is abolished in our
colonies, let us not forget that this fell
monster still exerts its cruel influence
over many parts of the globe. Upwards
of two millions of wretched slaves groan

beneath the last of the oppressor in the
United States of free America, and
the noble Poles are dying under the
weight of another (yoke) species of thraldom
if possible, still more galling. Let
not these be forgotten in our prayers
or our efforts.

And even as regards our own colonies
the work of mercy is still yet imperfect––
The personal emancipation of the Negro cannot
be regarded as fully answering his powerful
& peculiar claims. We owe him still a debt
which can only be discharged by combined &
comb persevering effort, prompted by benevolence,
& regulated by wisdom. Having in times past
done what we could to render him vile, we
should now do all in our power to elevate
him in the scale of being, &
